title: When to Use the "Less Than" (<) Inequality Symbol
text: $$a<b$$ “a is less than b” when a is to the left of $$b$$ on the number line

title: When to Use the "Greater Than" (>) Inequality Symbol
text: $$a>b$$ “a is greater than b” when a is to the right of $$b$$ on the number line

title: Example of a Number Line
text: In the picture attached to this hint is a number line indicating the positions of $$0.04$$ and $$0.4$$. We can see that $$0.04$$ is to the left of $$0.4$$ on the number line, so $$0.04<0.4$$. You can also see that this means $$0.4$$ is the right of $$0.04$$ on the number line, so $$0.4>0.04$$.\n##figure1.gif##

title: $$-0.5$$ Relative to $$-0.3$$ on the Number Line
text: $$-0.5$$ is to the left of $$-0.3$$ on the number line, showing that $$-0.5$$ is less than $$-0.3$$.
